title: Java ScannerhasNextByte()Method

metadata.description: Learn about Java ScannerhasNextByte()Method with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title:
Java Scanner
has
Method

Example
Print the value of every byte in the string
content_sections.content:
:
// Create a scanner object
Scanner myObj = new Scanner("A byte is a number between -128 and 127");

// Print the value of every byte in the scanner
while(myObj.has
  if(myObj.has
    System.out.println(myObj.
  } else {
    myObj.
  }
}
Definition and Usage
The
has
method returns
true
if the 
byte
data type, which is any whole number between -128 and 127.
If the
radix
parameter is used, then it interprets numbers using the radix. For example, a radix of 16 would interpret numbers as hexadecimal (digits 0 to 9 and A to F). If the
radix
parameter is not used then it interprets numbers using the scanner's radix, which is 10 by default but it can be changed with the
useRadix()
method.
What is a token?
A token is a sequence of characters separated from other tokens by delimiters. The default delimiter is a block of whitespace characters but it can be changed with the
useDelimiter()
method.
Syntax
One of the following:
public boolean has
public boolean has
radix
)
Parameter Values
Parameter
Description
radix
Optional. Specifies the radix used to interpret numbers. The radix specifies how many different symbols can be used to represent a digit in a number.

A

value which is true if the

value.

quiz.question: What is A byte?
What is which?
quiz.explanation: The correct definition of which is 'any whole number between -128 and 127'.

summary: This tutorial covers Java ScannerhasNextByte()Method concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use Java ScannerhasNextByte()Method effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of Java ScannerhasNextByte()Method and how to apply it in your projects.
